title: Basketball star impacting Senior High football team
text:
Activate your digital access. Basketball star impacting Senior High football team Mansfield Senior's Mario Young, an All-Ohioan in basketball, talks about his transition to football for the first time, while head football coach Chioke Bradley discusses the recruiting pitch he used on Young. Rob McCurdy/News Journal Rob McCurdy , Reporter 5:48 p.m. EDT October 7, 2015 Mansfield Senior's Mario Young is an All-Ohio basketball player competing in football for the first time and succeeding. Mansfield Senior's Mario Young manages to fire off a shot while falling during a tournament game against Perrysburg Friday night. Young is playing football for the first time for the Tygers. (Photo: Lisa Bernheim/News Journal) 
MANSFIELD — Chioke Bradley would watch Mario Young play basketball on winter Friday nights and wonder what he could do on the football field. 
Turns out, Young could do a lot. 
In just his first season as a high school football player, Young leads the Tygers in sacks and is second in tackles for loss. 
"I didn't recruit him too much," the Mansfield Senior head football coach said. "I basically was like, 'All your buddies are playing football, and it's your senior year. Wouldn't that be an amazing situation to finish out your senior year playing football with all your friends and doing some good and special things?'" 
Young finally relented. 
"I stopped (football after seventh grade) for basketball. Chioke wanted me to play since I was a freshman, so I decided to play. I probably should have played all four (years.)," Young said. 
On the basketball court, Bradley saw obviously athletic skills, but he also saw an aggressiveness and a demeanor that scream football player, even if he was a 6-foot-2, 190-pound, All-Ohio guard/forward. 
The coach knew if given a chance on the football field, Young would make the transition look easy. However, what surprised him is where Young would make his impact. 
"I envisioned him being a dog-gone, big-time receiver because of his jumping ability and his explosiveness to go along with his physical play," Bradley said. "I thought he was going to excel on that side of the ball. We tried him over there." 
But Young quickly realized he'd rather hit than be hit. 
"He kind of brought himself over here and distanced himself from the offensive side of the ball and starting showing up in a lot of our defensive drills," Bradley said. 
That was fine because there was a place for him on defense. In Mansfield Senior's scheme, Bradley likes to use lighter, yet faster ends, to rush the quarterback. Young was a prototype for that position with the Tygers. 
"As a staff, we just had to teach him a few things and let his athleticism and his physical, tough play that's instilled in him — that's in his DNA — take the rest," Bradley said. "We use him as a guy that we allow to run around and make plays in the backfield. If you've got a quarterback and your wide receivers can't get open, you're going to see Mo Young shortly because we're sending him to get you." 
Through six games, Young is tied for second in the area in sacks with six. He also has eight tackles for loss, one less than fellow defensive end Marvin Parker. Young has forced a fumble, and while he's not asked to be a run-stopper, he has 29 tackles, which ranks third on the squad. 
Basketball remains his No. 1 love, but he's transferring those skills to the football field. 
"It's definitely fun," Young said. 
Bradley wishes that fun started sooner. 
"It's fortunate for us that he was able to come out his senior year, but I wish he would have come out three years ago," the coach said, "then you never know what could happen for him. I'm glad he's here now."
